Description: Terracotta flask in the shape of a sitting ape. Mould-made, originally covered with red slip. The ape wears a cord around his neck from which hang two medallions and an amulet. There are two pierced holes for suspension in the rim on top of his head. Red-brown Nile silt.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Published as a Roman piece of the 1st-2nd century AD (Sakamoto 1999, 103, 211, no. 155). Sakamoto, N. 1999, Art of the Ancient Mediterranean World. Exhibition of objects from the Boston Museum of Fine Arts held from April 17, 1999 to March 2004 at Nagoya, Boston.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.614) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4595 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
